benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: DELETE /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails/{email} - Delete email from account

covered: DELETE Method - Valid Deletion: Multiple scenarios verify successful deletion returning 204 (TC01, TC02, TC12, TC13, TC14, TC18).
DELETE Method - Non-Existent Resource: 404 for missing account or email is validated (TC03, TC04, TC09).
DELETE Method - Concurrency: Race/concurrent deletes covered; one 204 and others 404 (TC15).
Input Validation: 400 responses for invalid accountId/email formats and malicious input (TC05, TC06, TC16).
Headers: Required X-Killbill-CreatedBy enforced (TC07); optional X-Killbill-Reason and X-Killbill-Comment exercised (TC02).
Robustness with extraneous query params: Endpoint tolerates extra param without breaking behavior (TC08).
Resilience/Server error handling: 503 for dependency failure simulated (TC11).
Operational characteristics: Response time threshold checked (TC14).
Reliability under transient failures: Retry succeeds after network glitch (TC19).
gaps: DELETE Method - Soft Deletes: No scenario verifies whether deletion is soft vs hard (e.g., flagged as deleted, recoverable, or visible in audit).
Idempotency (sequential): No test deleting the same email twice sequentially to confirm first 204 then 404 (or repeated 204 if defined).
Content negotiation/headers: No checks for response headers such as Content-Type for error responses and absence of body for 204 despite Produces: application/json note.
Path encoding: No test for URL-encoding of the email path segment (e.g., plus signs, spaces, UTF-8, or percent-encoding of @ and special characters).
Audit trail semantics: No verification that X-Killbill-CreatedBy/Reason/Comment are recorded in audit logs for the delete action.
Rate limiting/throttling: No scenario validating 429 or proper handling under burst deletes.
Security/permissions depth: Only generic 401 is covered; no 403 scenario for authenticated but unauthorized principal.
recommendations: Add a soft-delete verification scenario: perform delete, then query email list or audit endpoint to confirm soft vs hard delete behavior per product expectations.
Add an idempotency test: delete the same email twice sequentially; assert first call 204, second call 404 (or 204) according to spec.
Validate response headers: ensure 204 has no body and appropriate headers; ensure error responses include application/json Content-Type and structured error payload.
Add URL-encoding scenarios: attempt delete with emails containing special characters (+, %2B, spaces, Unicode/IDN) to verify correct routing and validation.
Include an audit trail check: after deletion, fetch audit logs to confirm CreatedBy/Reason/Comment were persisted.
Introduce rate limiting test: send high-frequency DELETE requests and expect 429 or documented behavior.
Add authorization depth test: authenticated user without required permission should receive 403, distinct from 401.
